Pests.Name: Brown Planthopper
Pests.Symptoms: Hopper burn, yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper water management, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infested plants.
Management.Biological: Encourage natural enemies like spiders and mirid bugs.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides like imidacloprid and buprofezin.

Pests.Name: Rice Leaf Folder
Pests.Symptoms: Folded leaves, leaf scraping, and white parallel streaks.

Management.Cultural: Use resistant varieties, avoid dense planting, and maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae and pupae.
Management.Biological: Release egg parasitoids like Trichogramma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as chlorpyrifos and lambda-cyhalothrin.

Pests.Name: Stem Borer
Pests.Symptoms: Deadhearts in young plants, whiteheads in mature plants, and boreholes in stems.

Management.Cultural: Plant early maturing varieties, use crop rotation, and remove stubble after harvest.
Management.Mechanical: Use light traps and pheromone traps to monitor and control adult moths.
Management.Biological: Release egg parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and use entomopathogenic nematodes.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as fipronil and cartap hydrochloride.

Pests.Name: Rice Hispa
Pests.Symptoms: Scraped leaf surface, white streaks, and dried leaf margins.

Management.Cultural: Avoid close planting, maintain field sanitation, and remove alternate hosts.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy adult beetles and larvae.
Management.Biological: Introduce parasitoids like Anagrus spp. and release predators like ladybird beetles.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as chlorpyrifos and monocrotophos.

Pests.Name: Rice Gall Midge
Pests.Symptoms: Silver shoot or onion shoot, stunted growth, and no grain formation.

Management.Cultural: Use resistant varieties, synchronize planting, and remove infested tillers.
Management.Mechanical: Use light traps to reduce adult populations.
Management.Biological: Encourage natural enemies like Platygaster oryzae and Aprostocetus spp.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as carbofuran and fipronil.

Diseases.Name: Blast
Diseases.Symptoms: Diamond-shaped lesions on leaves, grayish center, and brown margins.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper spacing, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as tricyclazole and carbendazim.

Diseases.Name: Bacterial Leaf Blight
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellowing of leaf margins, water-soaked lesions, and drying of leaves.

Management.Cultural: Use resistant varieties, maintain proper water management, and avoid field activities when plants are wet.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant residues.
Management.Biological: Use biocontrol agents like Pseudomonas fluorescens.
Management.Chemical: Spray with copper-based bactericides.

Diseases.Name: Sheath Blight
Diseases.Symptoms: Irregular greenish-gray lesions on leaf sheath, wilting, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant parts.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as hexaconazole and validamycin.

Diseases.Name: Tungro
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellowing and stunting of plants, reduced tillering, and sterility.

Management.Cultural: Use resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and synchronize planting.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Management.Biological: Encourage natural enemies like ladybird beetles.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides to control vector population (e.g., green leafhopper).

Diseases.Name: Brown Spot
Diseases.Symptoms: Brown lesions with yellow halo on leaves, leaf drying, and grain discoloration.

Management.Cultural: Use resistant varieties, avoid excessive nitrogen application, and maintain proper water management.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Pseudomonas fluorescens.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as mancozeb and carbendazim.

Pests.Name: Aphids
Pests.Symptoms: Curled leaves, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and lacewings.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Armyworms
Pests.Symptoms: Defoliation, cut stems, and grain damage.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae and pupae.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and predators like ground beetles.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as chlorantraniliprole and lambda-cyhalothrin.

Pests.Name: Hessian Fly
Pests.Symptoms: Stunted growth, dark green leaves, and plant lodging.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, delay planting, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy volunteer wheat plants and infested crop residues.
Management.Biological: Encourage natural enemies like parasitic wasps.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam as seed treatments.

Pests.Name: Wheat Stem Sawfly
Pests.Symptoms: Hollowed stems, plant lodging, and reduced grain yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, delay planting, and use trap crops.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infested stems and crop residues.
Management.Biological: Encourage natural enemies like parasitoid wasps.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides to reduce adult populations.

Pests.Name: Cereal Leaf Beetle
Pests.Symptoms: Striped feeding damage on leaves, reduced photosynthesis, and weakened plants.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae and adult beetles.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Tetrastichus julis and use predators like ladybird beetles.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as malathion and lambda-cyhalothrin.

Diseases.Name: Rust
Diseases.Symptoms: Orange-red pustules on leaves and stems, leaf drying, and reduced yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as propiconazole and mancozeb.

Diseases.Name: Powdery Mildew
Diseases.Symptoms: White powdery spots on leaves, leaf curling, and premature leaf death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant parts.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Bacillus subtilis.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as sulfur and trifloxystrobin.

Diseases.Name: Septoria Leaf Blotch
Diseases.Symptoms: Irregular brown lesions with yellow margins on leaves, leaf drying, and reduced grain filling.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Pseudomonas fluorescens.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as tebuconazole and prothioconazole.

Diseases.Name: Fusarium Head Blight
Diseases.Symptoms: Pinkish-white mold on heads, shriveled grains, and reduced yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, avoid excessive irrigation, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant residues.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as prothioconazole and tebuconazole.

Diseases.Name: Karnal Bunt
Diseases.Symptoms: Partial grain darkening, fishy odor, and reduced grain quality.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant parts.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Pseudomonas fluorescens.
Management.Chemical: Treat seeds with fungicides such as carboxin and thiram.

Pests.Name: Fall Armyworm
Pests.Symptoms: Leaf feeding, windowpane damage, and ragged leaf edges.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and predators like ladybird beetles.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as chlorantraniliprole and lambda-cyhalothrin.

Pests.Name: Stem Borer
Pests.Symptoms: Deadhearts in young plants, boreholes in stems, and tunneling in cobs.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and remove stubble after harvest.
Management.Mechanical: Use light traps and pheromone traps to monitor and control adult moths.
Management.Biological: Release egg parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and use entomopathogenic nematodes.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as fipronil and cartap hydrochloride.

Pests.Name: Corn Earworm
Pests.Symptoms: Feeding on kernels, silk damage, and mold growth on ears.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid monocropping.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and predators like ladybird beetles.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as spinosad and indoxacarb.

Pests.Name: Aphids
Pests.Symptoms: Sticky honeydew, curled leaves, and sooty mold growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and lacewings.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Cutworms
Pests.Symptoms: Cut seedlings at the base, wilting, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and predators like ground beetles.
Management.Chemical: Spray with insecticides such as chlorantraniliprole and lambda-cyhalothrin.

Diseases.Name: Gray Leaf Spot
Diseases.Symptoms: Rectangular lesions on leaves, yellow halos, and leaf blight.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as azoxystrobin and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Common Rust
Diseases.Symptoms: Reddish-brown pustules on leaves, leaf drying, and reduced photosynthesis.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as tebuconazole and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Northern Corn Leaf Blight
Diseases.Symptoms: Cigar-shaped lesions on leaves, leaf drying, and reduced grain filling.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as azoxystrobin and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Southern Corn Leaf Blight
Diseases.Symptoms: Small, tan lesions on leaves, leaf blight, and reduced grain filling.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as azoxystrobin and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Maize Dwarf Mosaic Virus
Diseases.Symptoms: Mosaic patterns on leaves, stunted growth, and reduced yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, control weed hosts, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Management.Biological: Use virus-free seeds and avoid planting in areas with high vector populations.
Management.Chemical: Control aphid vectors with insecticides like imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Shoot Fly
Pests.Symptoms: Deadhearts in young plants, boreholes in stems, and stunted growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, maintain field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infested plants.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as chlorpyrifos and fipronil.

Pests.Name: Shoot Bug
Pests.Symptoms: Leaf curling, stunted growth, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infested plants.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as chlorpyrifos and imidacloprid.

Diseases.Name: Downy Mildew
Diseases.Symptoms: White downy growth on leaves, stunted growth, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as metalaxyl and fosetyl-Al.

Diseases.Name: Anthracnose
Diseases.Symptoms: Irregular, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stalks, and panicles, leaf blight, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as azoxystrobin and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Grain Mold
Diseases.Symptoms: Discolored grains, mold growth on grains, and reduced grain quality.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, avoid late planting, and maintain proper field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as carbendazim and mancozeb.

Diseases.Name: Ergot
Diseases.Symptoms: Honeydew secretion on panicles, sclerotia formation, and reduced grain yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected panicles and sclerotia.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as carbendazim and mancozeb.

Diseases.Name: Smut
Diseases.Symptoms: Black, powdery masses in inflorescences, reduced grain yield, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant parts.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Treat seeds with fungicides such as carboxin and thiram.

Pests.Symptoms: Curling and yellowing of leaves, stunted growth, and honeydew secretion.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and lacewings.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Diseases.Name: Powdery Mildew

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as sulfur and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Net Blotch
Diseases.Symptoms: Brown, net-like lesions on leaves and leaf sheaths.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as azoxystrobin and propiconazole.

Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as tebuconazole and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Barley Yellow Dwarf Virus
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellowing and reddening of leaves, stunted growth, and reduced yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, control weed hosts, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Management.Biological: Use virus-free seeds and avoid planting in areas with high vector populations.
Management.Chemical: Control aphid vectors with insecticides like imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy grubs.
Management.Biological: Release entomopathogenic nematodes and use biopesticides like Beauveria bassiana.
Management.Chemical: Apply soil insecticides such as chlorpyrifos and imidacloprid.

Diseases.Name: Downy Mildew
Diseases.Symptoms: White downy growth on leaves, stunted growth, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as metalaxyl and fosetyl-Al.

Diseases.Name: Rust
Diseases.Symptoms: Orange-brown pustules on leaves and stems.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as tebuconazole and propiconazole.

Pests.Name: Stem Borer
Pests.Symptoms: Deadhearts in young plants, boreholes in stems, and tunneling in cobs.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and remove stubble after harvest.
Management.Mechanical: Use light traps and pheromone traps to monitor and control adult moths.
Management.Biological: Release egg parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and use entomopathogenic nematodes.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as fipronil and cartap hydrochloride.

Pests.Name: Aphids
Pests.Symptoms: Curled leaves, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and lacewings.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Grasshoppers
Pests.Symptoms: Defoliation, chewing of leaves, and stunted growth.

Management.Cultural: Maintain field hygiene, practice crop rotation, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy grasshoppers.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like birds and parasitic wasps.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as carbaryl and malathion.

Diseases.Name: Leaf Spot
Diseases.Symptoms: Brown to black spots on leaves, reduced photosynthesis, and stunted growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as mancozeb and carbendazim.

Diseases.Symptoms: White downy growth on leaves, stunted growth, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as metalaxyl and fosetyl-Al.

Diseases.Name: Rust
Diseases.Symptoms: Orange-brown pustules on leaves and stems.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as tebuconazole and propiconazole.

Pests.Name: Pod Borer
Pests.Symptoms: Holes in pods, feeding on seeds, and webbing of pods.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae and infested pods.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and predators like spiders.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as spinosad and chlorantraniliprole.

Pests.Name: Aphids
Pests.Symptoms: Curled leaves, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and lacewings.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Stem Fly
Pests.Symptoms: Boreholes in stems, wilting, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and remove stubble after harvest.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infested plants.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and use entomopathogenic nematodes.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as chlorpyrifos and fipronil.

Diseases.Name: Fusarium Wilt
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellowing of leaves, wilting, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant residues.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Treat seeds with fungicides such as carboxin and thiram.

Diseases.Name: Sterility Mosaic Virus
Diseases.Symptoms: Stunted growth, leaf mosaic, and sterility of flowers.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Management.Biological: Control vector mites with neem oil or other organic sprays.
Management.Chemical: Apply miticides such as abamectin and spiromesifen.

Diseases.Name: Phytophthora Blight
Diseases.Symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on stems, leaf wilting, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, avoid excessive irrigation, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as metalaxyl and fosetyl-Al.

Pests.Name: Aphids
Pests.Symptoms: Curled leaves, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles and lacewings.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Thrips
Pests.Symptoms: Silvery streaks on leaves, leaf curling, and stunted growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper field hygiene, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Use blue sticky traps to monitor and control thrips populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like predatory mites and minute pirate bugs.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as spinosad and emamectin benzoate.

Pests.Name: Pod Borer
Pests.Symptoms: Holes in pods, feeding on seeds, and webbing of pods.

Management.Cultural: Plant early-maturing varieties, practice crop rotation, and maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae and infested pods.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp. and predators like spiders.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as spinosad and chlorantraniliprole.

Diseases.Name: Powdery Mildew
Diseases.Symptoms: White, powdery spots on leaves, stems, and pods.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper plant spacing, and avoid excessive irrigation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant debris.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides such as sulfur and propiconazole.

Diseases.Name: Yellow Mosaic Virus
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellow patches on leaves, stunted growth, and reduced yield.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plants.
Management.Biological: Control whitefly vectors with neem oil or other organic sprays.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Diseases.Name: Root Rot
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellowing of leaves, wilting, and root decay.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain proper field hygiene, and practice crop rotation.
Management.Mechanical: Remove and destroy infected plant residues.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Treat seeds with fungicides such as carboxin and thiram.

Pests.Name: Pod Borer
Pests.Symptoms: Feeding holes on pods, Presence of larvae on the crop, Reduced pod formation and damaged seeds.

Management.Cultural: Sow early to avoid peak infestation, Intercrop with crops like coriander to reduce pest population.
Management.Mechanical: Handpick and destroy larvae and infested pods, Use pheromone traps to monitor and capture adult moths.
Management.Biological: Release parasitoids like Trichogramma spp, Encourage natural predators such as ladybird beetles and spiders.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as spinosad and chlorantraniliprole.

Pests.Name: Aphids
Pests.Symptoms: Curled leaves, honeydew secretion, and sooty mold growth.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene, and avoid excessive nitrogen application.
Management.Mechanical: Use yellow sticky traps to monitor aphid populations.
Management.Biological: Release natural enemies like ladybird beetles.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as imidacloprid and thiamethoxam.

Pests.Name: Cutworm
Pests.Symptoms: Cutting of young plants at the base near ground level, Wilted and dead seedlings.

Management.Cultural: Keep fields free from weeds and plant debris, Practice deep plowing to expose larvae.
Management.Mechanical: Use light traps to attract and kill adult moths, Handpick larvae in the evening when they are active.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Bacillus thuringiensis, Encourage natural predators like birds and predatory beetles.
Management.Chemical: Apply insecticides such as chlorpyrifos or lambda-cyhalothrin.

Diseases.Name: Fusarium Wilt
Diseases.Symptoms: Yellowing of leaves, wilting, and plant death.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, maintain field hygiene.
Management.Mechanical: Remove infected plant residues.
Management.Biological: Apply biocontrol agents like Trichoderma spp.
Management.Chemical: Treat seeds with fungicides such as carboxin.

Management.Cultural: Plant resistant varieties, avoid excessive irrigation.

Management.Chemical: Spray with fungicides like sulfur.
